KekulÃ© Cells for Molecular Computation

W.H. Hesselink 1, J.C. Hummelen 2, H.T. Jonkman 2,

Abstract

The configurations of single and double bonds in polycyclic hydrocarbons are abstracted as KekulÃ© states of graphs. Sending a so-called soliton over an open channel between ports (external nodes) of the graph changes the KekulÃ© state and therewith the set of open channels in the graph. This switching behaviour is proposed as a basis for molecular computation. The proposal is highly speculative but may have tremendous impact.

KekulÃ© states with the same boundary behaviour (port assignment) can be regarded as equivalent. This gives rise to the abstraction of KekulÃ© cells. The basic theory of KekulÃ© states and KekulÃ© cells is developed here, up to the classification of KekulÃ© cells with â‰¤4absent4\leq 4 ports. To put the theory in context, we generalize KekulÃ© states to semi-KekulÃ© states, which form the solutions of a linear system of equations over the field of the bits 0 and 1. We briefly study so-called omniconjugated graphs, in which every port assignment of the right signature has a KekulÃ© state. Omniconjugated graphs may be useful as connectors between computational elements. We finally investigate some examples with potentially useful switching behaviour.

1 Introduction

In the quest for smaller and smaller computational elements, we may hope to arrive one day at the level of molecules. Controllable electrical conductance within molecules is the realm of chemistry. One proposal in this direction is to use so-called Ï€ğœ‹\pi-conjugation in polycyclic hydrocarbons, as studied in Marleen van der Veenâ€™s PhD thesis â€œÏ€ğœ‹\pi-Logicâ€ [17].

The development of this field of Ï€ğœ‹\pi-conjugation and Ï€ğœ‹\pi-logic needs several abstractions that belong to branches of mathematics like graph theory and linear algebra. In mathematics, the symbol Ï€ğœ‹\pi is primarily associated with the circumference and the area of the circle. The term â€œconjugationâ€ has also several connotations in mathematics. In this paper, conjugation means the constructive interaction between a pair of neighbouring (carbon-carbon) Ï€ğœ‹\pi-orbitals, leading to delocalisation of the electrons.

The basic physical idea is that the configuration of single and double bonds in certain polycyclic â€˜aromaticâ€™ [note: these are polyunsaturated hydrocarbons, usually referred to as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), but they need not be aromatic in the strict chemical sense] hydrocarbons influences the electrical conductivity between points of the molecule, and can be influenced by electrical signals over channels in the molecule. In other words, the molecule can serve as a switch. Since it was KekulÃ© who proposed, in 1865, the alternating single and double bonds in the benzene ring (one of the simplest cyclic hydrocarbons), we prefer to associate the basic ideas to be exposed here with the name KekulÃ©.

The polycyclic hydrocarbons we are considering have boundary atoms that can serve as ports to probe and modify the electronic properties of the molecules. The electrical resistance between two ports is low when there is a path of alternating single and double bonds between them [20]. By sending a so-called soliton over the alternating path, the single and double bonds along the path are toggled [6]. Such toggling of an alternating path may open or close other alternating paths in the molecule. This is the switching behaviour alluded to. The toggling can also be done by chemical means (for example a redox reaction [1, 19]).

In our abstraction of the molecule, the graph of the atoms and bonds is kept fixed, while it is allowed to change the multiplicities (single or double) of the bonds. A configuration of bonds such that every internal node has precisely one double bond is called a KekulÃ© state. Nodes with precisely one edge to the remainder of the graph are called ports. The port assignment of a KekulÃ© state describes the multiplicities of the bonds at the ports. A pair of ports is called a channel. A channel is called open (low resistance) in a KekulÃ© state if there is an alternating path between its ports.

Another reason for naming the configurations KekulÃ© states is that they are to represent closed shell molecules (â€˜KekulÃ© structuresâ€™), i.e., molecules in which all electrons are paired, as opposed to non-KekulÃ© states.

The term â€˜KekulÃ© stateâ€™ has its chemical equivalent in â€˜resonance structureâ€™ (or â€˜resonance contributorâ€™), with the restriction of being a system that is closed-shell and without charges. The number of different KekulÃ© states of the graph is a measure of the stability of the molecule. In this sense, KekulÃ© states represent all structures that are regarded in the Valence Bond Theory [8, 7, 2, 15] of molecules (as opposed to Molecular Orbital Theory, that also includes charged and open shell configurations as parts for the total quantum mechanical description of the electronic structure of a molecule).

The KekulÃ© state is a debatable abstraction. The actual quantum-mechanical state is a weighted superposition of many states, in which the KekulÃ© states have high weights; e.g., the two KekulÃ© states of the benzene hexagon are just two components of a single quantum-mechanical state. This does not matter for the switching behaviour described, however, because it turns out that all KekulÃ© states with the same port assignment have the same open (closed) channels between ports, see Theorem 2.2 in section 2.2. It follows that the effect of sending a soliton over an open channel only effects the port assignment, and consists of toggling the port assignment only at the ports of the channel.

We introduce KekulÃ© cells to capture this behaviour. More precisely, we introduce a mathematical concept cell that captures the behaviour, and KekulÃ© cells are those that can be obtained from graphs with single and double bonds in them.

A serious physical objection is that the KekulÃ© states form a qualitative characteristic of the state, whereas the precise energy levels of the various eigen-states are quantitative. This objection must be dealt with when the qualitative investigations are leading to actual technical proposals.

Van der Veen et al.Â [18] have first proposed certain Ï€ğœ‹\pi-conjugated systems that can act as â€˜soldering pointsâ€™ for molecular wires in the sense that linear Ï€ğœ‹\pi-conjugated pathways between all ports (â€˜terminalsâ€™) exist; i.e., â€˜omniconjugatedâ€™ systems. Subsequently, Ï€ğœ‹\pi-logic [17] was proposed as a way to perform any Boolean operation within certain Ï€ğœ‹\pi-conjugated hydrocarbon frameworks, bearing a number of ports. We now formalize this approach in a rigorous mathematical and topological way.

The application of graph theory to chemistry is not new. One of the research areas is the search for quantitative structure-property relationships based on molecular connectivity invariants of the hydrogen-suppressed chemical graphs, see the overview article [13]. The invariants are numerical functions of graphs that can be related to properties of classes of compounds like, e.g., solubility, crystal density, melting point, etc. In [16], it is proposed that one of these invariants (a generalized Randic index) for a certain class of hydrocarbons can be interpreted as an energy functional that depends on the Ï€ğœ‹\pi-electron density. The paper [4] goes beyond numerical invariants and studies energy levels of Ï€ğœ‹\pi-conjugated systems by means of the symmetry groups of the graphs. In our application of graph theory, numerical invariants and the symmetry of the graphs play no roles yet.

1.1 Overview

The formalization steps we need are first sketched in section 1.2. In section 1.3, we present the mathematical notations that we need. The graph theory needed is presented in section 1.4.

In section 2, we present the theory of KekulÃ© states and KekulÃ© cells, up to the classification of KekulÃ© cells with four ports. Section 3 contains the theory of semi-KekulÃ© states. Here it is proved that the number of KekulÃ© states for a given port assignment is â‰¤2e+1âˆ’vabsentsuperscript2ğ‘’1ğ‘£\leq 2^{e+1-v} where eğ‘’e is the number of edges and vğ‘£v is the number of nodes of the graph. This section serves as an aside to provide context for the KekulÃ© states, but is not really needed for the application. In section 4, we discuss graphs for which the KekulÃ© cell is as large as possible; such graphs are said to be omniconjugated. In section 5, we investigate the functionality of cells for switching behaviour. Conclusions are drawn in section 6.

1.2 The formalization steps

We now briefly sketch the central concepts of the theory. Precise definitions are postponed.

It is natural and conventional to represent molecules by graphs with the nodes for atoms and the edges for bonds. Polycyclic polyunsaturated hydrocarbons are usually almost flat, so that their graphs are planar. We use a subgraph to indicate the set of double bonds of a given molecule.

Nodes of the graph that are linked via only one edge to the remainder of the graph are called ports. A port assignment is a set of ports used to indicate the ports that are to be attached by a double bond. The KekulÃ© cell associated to a graph with port set Pğ‘ƒP is the set of port assignments in Pğ‘ƒP that allow KekulÃ© states.

A cell in Pğ‘ƒP is defined to be an arbitrary set of port assignments in Pğ‘ƒP. A cell is a KekulÃ© cell if there is some graph for which the cell is the set of KekulÃ© port assignments. A functional cell is a cell together with an initial port assignment and a system of channels to probe and modify the current port assignment.

1.4 Undirected graphs

There is no standard terminology in graph theory, cf.Â [5]. In this note, all graphs are finite, undirected graphs without isolated nodes, multiple edges, or self-loops.

We formalize our graphs in the following way. The basic constituents of graphs are nodes (vertices). An edge is defined to be a set that consists of two distinct nodes. A graph is defined to be a finite set of edges. The nodes of a graph are the elements of its edges. If GğºG is a graph, we write nâ€‹Gğ‘›ğºnG for its set of nodes. The ports of graph GğºG are the nodes that occur in precisely one edge of GğºG (ports are called sites or terminals in [17]). We write pâ€‹Gğ‘ğºpG to denote the set of ports of graph GğºG. A node of GğºG is called internal if it is not a port. We write iâ€‹Gğ‘–ğºiG to denote the set of internal nodes of GğºG. So we have iâ€‹G=nâ€‹Gâˆ–pâ€‹Gğ‘–ğºğ‘›ğºğ‘ğºiG=nG\setminus pG.

The degree of a node vğ‘£v of graph GğºG is the number of edges of GğºG that contain vğ‘£v. Therefore, a node of GğºG is a port if and only if its degree is 1. In view of the application to conjugation in carbon chemistry, we could restrict attention to graphs where all nodes have degrees â‰¤4absent4\leq 4. Since we have no use for this restriction, we do this only in some examples.

We often represent graphs by drawing the nodes as bullets and the edges as line segments between the nodes. The graph drawn here has two ports and three internal nodes, one of degree 2 and two of degree 3.

Two distinct nodes pğ‘p and qğ‘q are defined to be connected in graph GğºG if there is a sequence of nodes (p0,â€¦,pn)subscriptğ‘0â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›(p_{0},\dots,p_{n}) with p0=psubscriptğ‘0ğ‘p_{0}=p and pn=qsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘p_{n}=q and (pi,pi+1)âˆˆGsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1ğº(p_{i},p_{i+1})\in G for all 0â‰¤i<n0ğ‘–ğ‘›0\leq i<n. Graph GğºG is called connected if it is nonempty and every pair of distinct nodes of GğºG is connected in GğºG. Graph GğºG is called a simple path between nodes pğ‘p and qğ‘q if it is connected, pğ‘p and qğ‘q are its only ports, and all its other nodes have degree 2. Graph GğºG is called a cycle if it is connected and all its nodes have degree 2.

Since a graph is just a set of edges, every subset of a graph GğºG is itself a graph, and can therefore be called a subgraph. A subgraph Cğ¶C of GğºG is called a curve in GğºG if every node of Cğ¶C which is internal in GğºG has degree 2 in Cğ¶C.

The empty subgraph is a curve. More interesting examples of curves are cycles, and simple paths between ports. Conversely, every connected component of a curve is a cycle or a simple path between ports.

2 KekulÃ© States

The concept of KekulÃ© states is motivated by their correspondence to Ï€ğœ‹\pi-conjugated systems in chemistry. Polycyclic polyunsaturated hydrocarbons are molecules in which carbon atoms are organized in rings, mainly hexagons, but possibly also pentagons and heptagons. The primary example would be naphthalene, consisting of two fused benzene rings.

In 1865, August KekulÃ© proposed that a benzene molecule should consist of a hexagon of carbon atoms with attached hydrogen in an alternating cycle of double bonds and single bonds. In our graph theoretical abstraction, we neglect all hydrogen atoms. All carbon atoms are represented by nodes of the graph, all bonds are represented by edges. So, they are the hydrogen suppressed chemical graphs of [13].

We represent the set of double bonds by a subgraph of the graph of the molecule. In common polycyclic polyunsaturated hydrocarbons, the rule is that every carbon atom is sp2 hybridized and has precisely one double bond. The ports represent other atoms that are linked to the graph by single or double bonds. This leads to the following definition.

We define a KekulÃ© state Wğ‘ŠW in graph GğºG to be a subgraph of GğºG such that every internal node of GğºG is a port of Wğ‘ŠW.

In graph theory, a subgraph Wğ‘ŠW of GğºG is called a perfect matching if every node of GğºG is a port of Wğ‘ŠW [5, p.Â 203]. It follows that Wğ‘ŠW is a perfect matching if and only if Wğ‘ŠW is a KekulÃ© state and Wğ‘ŠW contains all edges to ports.

Example 1

The graph shown in section 1.4 has no perfect matchings, and has two KekulÃ© states, one of which ({e,f}ğ‘’ğ‘“\{e,f\}) is shown below by doubling its edges eğ‘’e and fğ‘“f. If we give the bottom node an additional edge to a new port, the resulting graph has one perfect matching and four KekulÃ© states.

Efficient algorithms exist to determine whether a given graph has a perfect matching [10]. These algorithms can easily be adapted to yield KekulÃ© states. In the remainder of this paper, we have no need to consider perfect matchings.

Remark 1

There are graphs, even with several ports, that have no KekulÃ© states. The lefthand graph below is an example, as is easily verified. In this graph, the lower part with the two ports can be replaced by any other subgraph with any number of ports.

The righthand graph in the figure is a case with precisely one KekulÃ© state, even though the graph has two ports. In either case, the triangles can be replaced by pentagons to better meet the possibilities of carbon chemistry.

The chemical equivalents of the two structures are depicted below. The structure at the left is an open shell (non-KekulÃ©) radical structure with the bullet at a KekulÃ© violation. The structure at the right is a closed shell (KekulÃ©) structure.

2.1 Alternating curves

The electronic properties of KekulÃ© states are observed at and controlled by alternating paths, or more generally alternating curves.

An alternating curve is a pair (C,W)ğ¶ğ‘Š(C,W) of subgraphs of GğºG such that Cğ¶C is a curve in GğºG and that the intersection Wâˆ©Cğ‘Šğ¶W\cap C is a KekulÃ© state of Cğ¶C. Since all internal nodes of Cğ¶C have degree 2, this means that every internal node of Cğ¶C belongs to one edge of Wğ‘ŠW and one edge of Câˆ–Wğ¶ğ‘ŠC\setminus W, whence the name â€œalternatingâ€.

Roughly speaking, the next result says that the difference between any two KekulÃ© states is an alternating curve, and that, if at least one KekulÃ© state exists, every alternating curve is obtained in this way.

2.2 Port assignments

We now want to prescribe the port behaviour of KekulÃ© states. Let GğºG be a graph with a set of ports Pğ‘ƒP. We define a port assignment (â€œarchetypeâ€ in [17]) to be a subset of Pğ‘ƒP. For any subgraph Wğ‘ŠW of GğºG, we define W|Pconditionalğ‘Šğ‘ƒW|P as the set of nodes of Wğ‘ŠW that also belong to Pğ‘ƒP, i.e.,Â (W|P)=Pâˆ©nâ€‹Wconditionalğ‘Šğ‘ƒğ‘ƒğ‘›ğ‘Š(W|P)=P\cap nW. A port assignment gğ‘”g is called KekulÃ© if there is a KekulÃ© state Wğ‘ŠW of GğºG with g=(W|P)ğ‘”conditionalğ‘Šğ‘ƒg=(W|P).

In chemistry, the different KekulÃ© states with the same port assignment are called resonance structures. The actual quantum mechanical state is a superposition of these resonance structures. In the Valence Bond Theory picture, the actual quantum mechanical state is taken as a weighted superposition of these (neutral) resonance structures. The number of neutral closed shell resonance structures is determined by the number of alternating curves in the following way:

Corollary 1

Let GğºG be a graph with pâ€‹G=Pğ‘ğºğ‘ƒpG=P. Let gğ‘”g be a port assignment in Pğ‘ƒP. Let nğ‘›n be the number of KekulÃ© states Wğ‘ŠW of GğºG with (W|P)=gconditionalğ‘Šğ‘ƒğ‘”(W|P)=g. For every KekulÃ© state Wğ‘ŠW with (W|P)=gconditionalğ‘Šğ‘ƒğ‘”(W|P)=g, there are precisely nğ‘›n curves Cğ¶C without ports such that (C,W)ğ¶ğ‘Š(C,W) is alternating (including the empty curve).

Proof

This follows from Theorem 2.1 by the observation that Wğ‘ŠW and Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime} give the same port assignments if and only if the curve WâŠ•Wâ€²direct-sumğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Šâ€²W\oplus W^{\prime} has no ports. â–¡â–¡\Box

Example 2

Phenantrene consists of three hexagons without any ports. One of its KekulÃ© states is depicted here.

This KekulÃ© state has five alternating curves. Four of them are easy to find: the empty curve, two cycles of length 6 around the extreme hexagons, and one cycle of length 10 around the two horizontal neighbouring hexagons. The remaining alternating curve is disconnected: it is the union of the two cycles of length 6. Phenantrene has therefore five KekulÃ© states. â–¡â–¡\Box

In chemistry, i.e., within Valence Bond Theory, the number of KekulÃ© states of a port assignment is an indication of its stability. Here the KekulÃ© structures having the highest number of aromatic rings (rings with 4â€‹n+24ğ‘›24n+2 electrons; usually 6, as in benzene) are considered as the most important resonance contributors.

We now come to the central result of this paper that says that the existence of an alternating path between two given ports is completely determined by the set of KekulÃ© port assignments. It follows that the switching behavour of the graph is also completely determined by the set of KekulÃ© port assignments and hence independent of all other aspects of the graph.

In order to formulate this result, we note that, for distinct ports pğ‘p and qğ‘q, the doubleton set {p,q}ğ‘ğ‘\{p,q\} is a port assignment.

Theorem 2.2

Let port assignment kğ‘˜k satisfy k=(W|P)ğ‘˜conditionalğ‘Šğ‘ƒk=(W|P) for some KekulÃ© state Wğ‘ŠW. Let pğ‘p and qğ‘q be distinct ports. Proof

It satisfies (Wâ€²|P)=kâŠ•{p,q}conditionalsuperscriptğ‘Šâ€²ğ‘ƒdirect-sumğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘(W^{\prime}|P)=k\oplus\{p,q\}.

Conversely, if the port assignment kâŠ•{p,q}direct-sumğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘k\oplus\{p,q\} is KekulÃ©, let Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime} be a KekulÃ© state with (Wâ€²|P)=kâŠ•{p,q}conditionalsuperscriptğ‘Šâ€²ğ‘ƒdirect-sumğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘(W^{\prime}|P)=k\oplus\{p,q\} and let Câ€²=WâŠ•Wâ€²superscriptğ¶â€²direct-sumğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Šâ€²C^{\prime}=W\oplus W^{\prime}. Then (Câ€²,W)superscriptğ¶â€²ğ‘Š(C^{\prime},W) is an alternating curve by Theorem 2.1(a). The KekulÃ© states Wğ‘ŠW and Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime} agree on all ports except for pğ‘p and qğ‘q. Therefore, the graph Câ€²superscriptğ¶â€²C^{\prime} only contains the ports pğ‘p and qğ‘q. Let Cğ¶C be the connected component of pğ‘p in Câ€²superscriptğ¶â€²C^{\prime}. Then it also contains qğ‘q and (C,W)ğ¶ğ‘Š(C,W) is a simple alternating path from pğ‘p to qğ‘q in GğºG. â–¡â–¡\Box

Theorem 2.2 implies that all KekulÃ© states corresponding to a given KekulÃ© port assignment agree on the question which ports are connected by alternating paths, and that the result is determined completely by the set of KekulÃ© port assignments.

The physical relevance of Theorem 2.2 is that an alternating path between a pair of ports is, electrically, an open channel (low resistance), and that the channel is closed in the absence of alternating paths [11, 9, 3]. This leads to the following formal definitions.

In view of Theorem 2.2, we define a channel to be a port assignment of the form {p,q}ğ‘ğ‘\{p,q\} for distinct ports pğ‘p and qğ‘q. A channel cğ‘c is defined to be open with respect to a set Kğ¾K of port assignments and an element kâˆˆKğ‘˜ğ¾k\in K if and only if kâŠ•câˆˆKdirect-sumğ‘˜ğ‘ğ¾k\oplus c\in K.

The idea is that Kğ¾K stands for the set of KekulÃ© port assignments of some graph. If a channel cğ‘c is open for kâˆˆKğ‘˜ğ¾k\in K, one can send a so-called soliton through the channel with the effect that state kğ‘˜k is replaced by kâŠ•cdirect-sumğ‘˜ğ‘k\oplus c [17]. Indeed, the element kâˆˆKğ‘˜ğ¾k\in K is regarded as a memory state. It is up to the physics to determine how long such memory states can be preserved.

Example 3

One of the simplest cases is an ethene molecule with three attached ports p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}, p1subscriptğ‘1p_{1}, p2subscriptğ‘2p_{2}. The initial port assignment is âˆ…\emptyset. We use the channels A={p0,p1}ğ´subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1A=\{p_{0},p_{1}\} and T={p0,p2}ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘2T=\{p_{0},p_{2}\}. There are three KekulÃ© states, as depicted below. The corresponding port assignments are âˆ…\emptyset, Ağ´A and AâŠ•T={p1,p2}direct-sumğ´ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2A\oplus T=\{p_{1},p_{2}\}. Port assignment Tğ‘‡T is non-KekulÃ©.

Initially, channel Ağ´A is open and Tğ‘‡T is closed. When Ağ´A is signalled, we arrive at the middle state: this opens Tğ‘‡T, while Ağ´A remains open. If Ağ´A is signalled again, we return to the initial state where Tğ‘‡T is closed. We may use the system as a simple switch to open and close Tğ‘‡T by means of Ağ´A. Note, however, that if Ağ´A opens Tğ‘‡T, and Tğ‘‡T is then read, i.e., is signalled, we arrive at the righthand state where channel Ağ´A is closed. Therefore, in order to preserve the system as a switch, reading this memory cell must be done by signalling the channel twice. â–¡â–¡\Box

2.3 Abstraction from the graphs

At this point we take the abstraction step to concentrate on the ports and the port assignments and treat the specific graph itself merely as auxiliary. From here on, Pğ‘ƒP is an arbitrary finite set and the elements of Pğ‘ƒP are called ports. The subsets of Pğ‘ƒP are called port assignments. Just as before, a channel is a port assignment of the form {p,q}ğ‘ğ‘\{p,q\} for distinct ports pğ‘p and qğ‘q.

Recall from section 1.3 that the set Powâ€‹(P)Powğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Pow}}(P) of the port assignments is a commutative group with operation âŠ•direct-sum\oplus. We define Evenâ€‹(P)Evenğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Even}}(P) and Oddâ€‹(P)Oddğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Odd}}(P) to be the subsets of Powâ€‹(P)Powğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Pow}}(P) that consist of the port asignments with an even (odd) number of ports. It is easy to verify that Evenâ€‹(P)Evenğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Even}}(P) is a subgroup of Powâ€‹(P)Powğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Pow}}(P) and that Oddâ€‹(P)Oddğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Odd}}(P) is not.

For #â€‹P=4#ğ‘ƒ4\#P=4, the sets Evenâ€‹(P)Evenğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Even}}(P) and Oddâ€‹(P)Oddğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Odd}}(P) are depicted in Figure 5.5 of [17]. Table 5.10 of [17] gives the table of the operation âŠ•direct-sum\oplus in Evenâ€‹(P)Evenğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Even}}(P). The group Evenâ€‹(P)Evenğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Even}}(P) acts on Oddâ€‹(P)Oddğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Odd}}(P) in the sense that gâŠ•hâˆˆOddâ€‹(P)direct-sumğ‘”â„Oddğ‘ƒg\oplus h\in\mbox{{Odd}}(P) for all gâˆˆEvenâ€‹(P)ğ‘”Evenğ‘ƒg\in\mbox{{Even}}(P) and hâˆˆOddâ€‹(P)â„Oddğ‘ƒh\in\mbox{{Odd}}(P). All channels are elements of Evenâ€‹(P)Evenğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Even}}(P).

For any two port assignments kğ‘˜k, kâ€²âˆˆPowâ€‹(P)superscriptğ‘˜â€²Powğ‘ƒk^{\prime}\in\mbox{{Pow}}(P), we define the Hamming distance distâ€‹(k,kâ€²)distğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜â€²\mbox{{dist}}(k,k^{\prime}) as the number of ports in kâŠ•kâ€²direct-sumğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜â€²k\oplus k^{\prime}. Recall that, in any group, translation is the operation that adds a fixed element to its argument. The Hamming distance is translation invariant: distâ€‹(gâŠ•k,gâŠ•kâ€²)=distâ€‹(k,kâ€²)distdirect-sumğ‘”ğ‘˜direct-sumğ‘”superscriptğ‘˜â€²distğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜â€²\mbox{{dist}}(g\oplus k,g\oplus k^{\prime})=\mbox{{dist}}(k,k^{\prime}) for all gğ‘”g, kğ‘˜k, kâ€²âˆˆPowâ€‹(P)superscriptğ‘˜â€²Powğ‘ƒk^{\prime}\in\mbox{{Pow}}(P).

2.4 Cells and KekulÃ© cells

A cell over Pğ‘ƒP is defined to be a subset of Powâ€‹(P)Powğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Pow}}(P). 2.5 Transforming the graph while preserving its KekulÃ© cell

If it exists, let e0subscriptğ‘’0e_{0} be the edge between u1subscriptğ‘¢1u_{1} and u2subscriptğ‘¢2u_{2}. Let E1subscriptğ¸1E_{1} be the set of the other edges incident with u1subscriptğ‘¢1u_{1} and let E2subscriptğ¸2E_{2} be the set of the other edges incident with u2subscriptğ‘¢2u_{2}. Every KekulÃ© state Wğ‘ŠW of GğºG has e1âˆˆWsubscriptğ‘’1ğ‘Še_{1}\in W if and only if e2âˆ‰Wsubscriptğ‘’2ğ‘Še_{2}\notin W. It follows that Wğ‘ŠW contains precisely one of the edges in E1âˆªE2subscriptğ¸1subscriptğ¸2E_{1}\cup E_{2} and that e0âˆ‰Wsubscriptğ‘’0ğ‘Še_{0}\notin W if e0subscriptğ‘’0e_{0} exists. We can therefore transform Wğ‘ŠW into a KekulÃ© state of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} with the same values on all remaining edges. The details about neighbour vğ‘£v are left to the reader. It is easy to see that all KekulÃ© states of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} are obtained in this way. Because the transformation does not change the ports, the KekulÃ© cells of GğºG and Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} are equal. â–¡â–¡\Box

This result can also be used in the other direction, i.e., starting with graph Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}. In this way, it can serve to split a node with a high degree into two nodes with a lower degree. By first merging and then splitting, it can also be used to shift edges between nodes u1subscriptğ‘¢1u_{1} and u2subscriptğ‘¢2u_{2} in a similar way as with operation Op.vii of [17, section 3.3.1].

3 Semi-KekulÃ© States

This section serves as an aside to provide a context in which KekulÃ© states are special cases. We weaken the condition for KekulÃ© states to a linear condition over the field with two elements. This simplifies the mathematics, since the whole theory of linear equations becomes available.

For an integer xğ‘¥x, we write xâ€‹Â modÂ â€‹2ğ‘¥Â modÂ 2x\mbox{{\ mod }}2 to denote the remainder of xğ‘¥x upon integer division by 2. It follows that xâ€‹Â modÂ â€‹2=0ğ‘¥Â modÂ 20x\mbox{{\ mod }}2=0 (or 111) if and only if xğ‘¥x is even (or odd, respectively). For integers xğ‘¥x and yğ‘¦y, we define xâŠ•y=(x+y)â€‹Â modÂ â€‹2direct-sumğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Â modÂ 2x\oplus y=(x+y)\mbox{{\ mod }}2.

A node in a graph is called even/odd if its degree in the graph is even/odd. A subgraph Wğ‘ŠW of GğºG is called a semi-KekulÃ© state of GğºG if every internal node of GğºG is an odd node of Wğ‘ŠW. Clearly, every KekulÃ© state is a semi-KekulÃ© state, but not vice versa.

For any graph GğºG, we define oddâ€‹(G)oddğº\mbox{{odd}}(G) to be the set of odd nodes of GğºG. Therefore, Wğ‘ŠW is a semi-KekulÃ© state of GğºG if and only if iâ€‹GâŠ†oddâ€‹(W)ğ‘–ğºoddğ‘ŠiG\subseteq\mbox{{odd}}(W). Since every edge contributes twice to the degree of a node, the sum of the degrees of the nodes is twice the number of edges. It is therefore even. Since the sum of the degrees at the even nodes is also even, it follows that the sum of the degrees of the odd nodes is even. Since every odd node contributes an odd number, it follows that the number of odd nodes is even: #â€‹oddâ€‹(G)â€‹Â modÂ â€‹2=0#oddğºÂ modÂ 20\#\mbox{{odd}}(G)\mbox{{\ mod }}2=0 for every graph GğºG.

3.1 There are enough semi-KekulÃ© states

Let the signature of a graph GğºG be defined as the number sâ€‹G=(#â€‹iâ€‹G)â€‹modÂ â€‹2ğ‘ ğº#ğ‘–ğºmodÂ 2sG=(\#iG)\,\mbox{{mod }}2. In other words, the signature is 0 or 1, depending on whether the number of internal nodes is even or odd. To formulate the next result conveniently, we define Powâ€‹(P)0=Evenâ€‹(P)Powsubscriptğ‘ƒ0Evenğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{0}=\mbox{{Even}}(P) and Powâ€‹(P)1=Oddâ€‹(P)Powsubscriptğ‘ƒ1Oddğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{1}=\mbox{{Odd}}(P), see section 2.3.

3.2 The homogeneous semi-KekulÃ© kernel

Let ğ”¹ğ”¹\mathbb{B}Â (pronounced Bit) be the set of the two elements 0 and 1, with the addition âŠ•direct-sum\oplus described above and an ordinary multiplication. This is a field, i.e., an algebraic structure with the usual laws for addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division by nonzero elements. It follows that the whole theory of vector spaces and linear equations is applicable over ğ”¹ğ”¹\mathbb{B}.

In particular, for a set Pğ‘ƒP, the additive group Powâ€‹(P)Powğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Pow}}(P) is a vector space over ğ”¹ğ”¹\mathbb{B}Â of dimension #â€‹P#ğ‘ƒ\#P. The easiest way to see this is to identify a subset gâŠ†Pğ‘”ğ‘ƒg\subseteq P with its characteristic function Ï‡gsubscriptğœ’ğ‘”\chi_{g} given by Ï‡gâ€‹(p)=1subscriptğœ’ğ‘”ğ‘1\chi_{g}(p)=1 if pâˆˆgğ‘ğ‘”p\in g and Ï‡gâ€‹(p)=0subscriptğœ’ğ‘”ğ‘0\chi_{g}(p)=0 if pâˆ‰gğ‘ğ‘”p\notin g. In this way Powâ€‹(P)Powğ‘ƒ\mbox{{Pow}}(P) is identified with the set of functions Pâ†’ğ”¹â†’ğ‘ƒğ”¹P\to\mbox{$\mathbb{B}$}. The symmetric difference operator âŠ•direct-sum\oplus corresponds to the operator on functions given by (fâŠ•g)â€‹(p)=fâ€‹(p)âŠ•gâ€‹(p)direct-sumğ‘“ğ‘”ğ‘direct-sumğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘(f\oplus g)(p)=f(p)\oplus g(p).

The vector space Powâ€‹(G)Powğº\mbox{{Pow}}(G) is introduced in the same way. We define the homogeneous semi-KekulÃ© kernel, HSKâ€‹(G)HSKğº\mbox{{HSK}}(G), of GğºG to be the set of subgraphs Wğ‘ŠW for which all nodes are even:

HSKâ€‹(G)={WâˆˆPowâ€‹(G)âˆ£oddâ€‹(W)=âˆ…}HSKğºconditional-setğ‘ŠPowğºoddğ‘Š\mbox{{HSK}}(G)=\{W\in\mbox{{Pow}}(G)\mid\mbox{{odd}}(W)=\emptyset\} .

It is easy to see that HSK is a linear subspace of Powâ€‹(G)Powğº\mbox{{Pow}}(G).

If an inhomogeneous system of linear equations has a solution W0subscriptğ‘Š0W_{0}, the set of all its solutions is of the form W0âŠ•Hdirect-sumsubscriptğ‘Š0ğ»W_{0}\oplus H, where Hğ»H is the set of solutions of the homogeneous linear system. It follows that, given one semi-KekulÃ© state W0subscriptğ‘Š0W_{0} of GğºG, the set of semi-KekulÃ© states with the same port assignment as W0subscriptğ‘Š0W_{0} is equal to W0âŠ•HSKâ€‹(G)={W0âŠ•Wâˆ£WâˆˆHSKâ€‹(G)}direct-sumsubscriptğ‘Š0HSKğºconditional-setdirect-sumsubscriptğ‘Š0ğ‘Šğ‘ŠHSKğºW_{0}\oplus\mbox{{HSK}}(G)=\{W_{0}\oplus W\mid W\in\mbox{{HSK}}(G)\}.

A graph is called a tree if it is connected and has no connected proper subgraph with the same set of nodes. Every connected graph has a spanning tree, i.e., a subgraph with the same nodes which is a tree (just remove edges one by one until you would cause disconnectedness).

Theorem 3.2

Let graph GğºG be connected. The vector space HSKâ€‹(G)HSKğº\mbox{{HSK}}(G) over ğ”¹ğ”¹\mathbb{B} has dimension #â€‹G+1âˆ’#â€‹nâ€‹G#ğº1#ğ‘›ğº\#G+1-\#nG. It has a basis over ğ”¹ğ”¹\mathbb{B}Â that consists of cycles of GğºG.

Proof

First, assume that GğºG is a tree. Then the number of nodes is one plus the number of edges, as is well-known in graph theory. So we have #â€‹nâ€‹G=#â€‹G+1#ğ‘›ğº#ğº1\#nG=\#G+1. On the other hand, since GğºG is a tree, one can prove by induction on the size of the tree that HSKâ€‹(G)={âˆ…}HSKğº\mbox{{HSK}}(G)=\{\emptyset\}. This implies the assertion for the case that GğºG is a tree.

We now proceed by induction on the number of edges. Let graph GğºG be given. We may assume that GğºG is connected and not a tree. Therefore GğºG contains an edge eğ‘’e, such that removal of eğ‘’e yields a connected graph Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}. By induction, the space HSKâ€‹(Gâ€²)HSKsuperscriptğºâ€²\mbox{{HSK}}(G^{\prime}) of the subgraphs Wğ‘ŠW of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} with oddâ€‹(W)oddğ‘Š\mbox{{odd}}(W) empty has dimension #â€‹Gâˆ’#â€‹nâ€‹G#ğº#ğ‘›ğº\#G-\#nG and a basis BğµB that consists of cycles of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}. Since graph Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} is connected, edge eğ‘’e is contained in a cycle Cğ¶C of graph GğºG. Now Cğ¶C is an element of HSKâ€‹(G)âˆ–HSKâ€‹(Gâ€²)HSKğºHSKsuperscriptğºâ€²\mbox{{HSK}}(G)\setminus\mbox{{HSK}}(G^{\prime}). Therefore HSKâ€‹(Gâ€²)HSKsuperscriptğºâ€²\mbox{{HSK}}(G^{\prime}) is a proper subset of HSKâ€‹(G)HSKğº\mbox{{HSK}}(G). Since HSKâ€‹(Gâ€²)HSKsuperscriptğºâ€²\mbox{{HSK}}(G^{\prime}) is the subset of HSKâ€‹(G)HSKğº\mbox{{HSK}}(G) given by the single equation that corresponds to the condition eâˆ‰Wğ‘’ğ‘Še\notin W, it follows that dimâ€‹(HSKâ€‹(G))=1+dimâ€‹(HSKâ€‹(Gâ€²))=#â€‹G+1âˆ’#â€‹nâ€‹GdimHSKğº1dimHSKsuperscriptğºâ€²#ğº1#ğ‘›ğº\mbox{{dim}}(\mbox{{HSK}}(G))=1+\mbox{{dim}}(\mbox{{HSK}}(G^{\prime}))=\#G+1-\#nG and that Bâˆª{C}ğµğ¶B\cup\{C\} is a basis of HSKâ€‹(G)HSKğº\mbox{{HSK}}(G). â–¡â–¡\Box

This result was inspired by the observation that, for each of the graphs considered in Figures 5.7 and 5.8 of [17], the set HSKâ€‹(G)HSKğº\mbox{{HSK}}(G) has 8 elements.

Corollary 3

Let GğºG be connected. Let C0subscriptğ¶0C_{0}, â€¦, Crâˆ’1subscriptğ¶ğ‘Ÿ1C_{r-1} be cycles in GğºG such that r=#â€‹G+1âˆ’#â€‹nâ€‹Gğ‘Ÿ#ğº1#ğ‘›ğºr=\#G+1-\#nG and that C0subscriptğ¶0C_{0}, â€¦, Crâˆ’1subscriptğ¶ğ‘Ÿ1C_{r-1} are linearly independent over ğ”¹ğ”¹\mathbb{B}.
(a) Then C0subscriptğ¶0C_{0}, â€¦, Crâˆ’1subscriptğ¶ğ‘Ÿ1C_{r-1} form a basis of HSKâ€‹(G)HSKğº\mbox{{HSK}}(G).
(b) Let P=pâ€‹Gğ‘ƒğ‘ğºP=pG and Îµ=sâ€‹Gğœ€ğ‘ ğº{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}}=sG. For any gâˆˆPowâ€‹(P)Îµğ‘”Powsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ€g\in\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}}, there are precisely 2rsuperscript2ğ‘Ÿ2^{r} semi-KekulÃ© states Wğ‘ŠW with (W|P)=gconditionalğ‘Šğ‘ƒğ‘”(W|P)=g.

From part (b) it follows that the number of KekulÃ© states with a given port assignment is â‰¤2rabsentsuperscript2ğ‘Ÿ\leq 2^{r}.

Usually, it is very easy to find enough linearly independent cycles to obtain a basis for HSK with Corollary 3, and to find simple paths between different ports. Since the constructive proof of Theorem 3.1 is not very efficient, we prefer to apply Gauss elimination to the inhomogeneous system to find semi-KekulÃ© states.

Complexity. The problem to determine some KekulÃ© state for a given graph with given port assignment, has a complicated but efficient solution with complexity ğ’ªâ€‹(#â€‹Eâ‹…#â€‹V)ğ’ªâ‹…#ğ¸#ğ‘‰{\cal O}(\#E\cdot\sqrt{\#V}) [10]. All semi-KekulÃ© states can easily be found in time ğ’ªâ€‹(#â€‹Eâ‹…#â€‹V)ğ’ªâ‹…#ğ¸#ğ‘‰{\cal O}(\#E\cdot\#V). The above approach leads to an algorithm to determine all KekulÃ© states in time ğ’ªâ€‹(#â€‹Eâ‹…(#â€‹V+2r))ğ’ªâ‹…#ğ¸#ğ‘‰superscript2ğ‘Ÿ{\cal O}(\#E\cdot(\#V+2^{r})) where rğ‘Ÿr is as in Corollary 3. In the applications, this is quite feasible, since rğ‘Ÿr tends to be rather small.

4 Omniconjugated Graphs

Van der Veen et al.Â [18] have defined nğ‘›n-port (â€˜nğ‘›n-terminalâ€™) Ï€ğœ‹\pi-conjugated molecules, with nâ‰¥3ğ‘›3n\geq 3, as omniconjugated of type A, if direct linear conjugated pathways are present between all pairs of ports in all states of the ports. We now formalize the principles of such systems in a mathematical way.

We define a graph GğºG with signature Îµğœ€\varepsilon to be omniconjugated if P=pâ€‹Gğ‘ƒğ‘ğºP=pG has at least two elements and the KekulÃ© cell of GğºG is Powâ€‹(P)ÎµPowsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ€\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}} (i.e., maximal). Note that our concept omniconjugated represents what is called â€œomniconjugated of Type Aâ€ in [18, 17].

Corollary 4

Let GğºG be omniconjugated. Let Wğ‘ŠW be a KekulÃ© state of GğºG. Let pğ‘p and qğ‘q be two different ports of GğºG. Then GğºG has an alternating curve (C,W)ğ¶ğ‘Š(C,W), such that Cğ¶C is a simple path from pğ‘p to qğ‘q.

Proof

Since (W|P)âŠ•{p,q}âˆˆPowâ€‹(P)Îµdirect-sumconditionalğ‘Šğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘Powsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ€(W|P)\oplus\{p,q\}\in\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}}, and the graph is omniconjugated, the assertion follows from Theorem 2.2. â–¡â–¡\Box

The corollary means that all channels of an omniconjugated graph are always open (low resistance). Conversely, if graph GğºG has at least one KekulÃ© state and all channels are always open, it is omniconjugated.

For every set Pğ‘ƒP with at least two elements, omniconjugated graphs exist. This is shown as follows. Let A2subscriptğ´2A_{2} be the graph that consists of one edge with its two nodes. The two nodes are ports. In this case, Îµ=0ğœ€0{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}}=0 and Powâ€‹(P)ÎµPowsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ€\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}} contains the empty subgraph and the full subgraph which are both KekulÃ© states. Therefore A2subscriptğ´2A_{2} is omniconjugated. More generally, the linear graph Ansubscriptğ´ğ‘›A_{n} of nâ‰¥2ğ‘›2n\geq 2 consecutive nodes and nâˆ’1ğ‘›1n-1 edges is also omniconjugated (the name Ansubscriptğ´ğ‘›A_{n} comes from the classification of Dynkin diagrams).

The smallest omniconjugated graph with â‰¥3absent3\geq 3 ports is the graph Î”3subscriptÎ”3\Delta_{3} with 3 ports, and three internal nodes of degree 3 that form a triangle. More generally, let Gnsubscriptğºğ‘›G_{n} for nâ‰¥2ğ‘›2n\geq 2 be the complete graph with nğ‘›n nodes and (n2)binomialğ‘›2{n\choose 2} edges. Let Î”nsubscriptÎ”ğ‘›\Delta_{n} be the graph obtained from Gnsubscriptğºğ‘›G_{n} by attaching a port via an edge to every node of Gnsubscriptğºğ‘›G_{n}. So, Î”nsubscriptÎ”ğ‘›\Delta_{n} has 2â€‹n2ğ‘›2n nodes and (n2)+nbinomialğ‘›2ğ‘›{n\choose 2}+n edges. Note that Î”2=A4subscriptÎ”2subscriptğ´4\Delta_{2}=A_{4} and that Î”4subscriptÎ”4\Delta_{4} is the graph used for K5subscriptğ¾5K_{5} in the proof of Lemma 2. We leave it to the reader to verify that all graphs Î”nsubscriptÎ”ğ‘›\Delta_{n} with nâ‰¥2ğ‘›2n\geq 2 are omniconjugated. Conversely, we have:

Lemma 3

Let GğºG be a graph with nâ‰¥2ğ‘›2n\geq 2 nodes. Let graph Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} be obtained from GğºG by attaching a port via an edge to every node of GğºG. Assume that Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} is omniconjugated. Then GğºG is a complete graph.

Proof

Since GğºG has no isolated nodes, all nodes of GğºG are internal nodes of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}, and Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} has nğ‘›n ports. Therefore, the signature Îµğœ€\varepsilon of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} is nâ€‹Â modÂ â€‹2ğ‘›Â modÂ 2n\mbox{{\ mod }}2. Let Pğ‘ƒP be the set of ports of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}.

It suffices to prove that every pair of different nodes of GğºG is linked in GğºG. Let uâ‰ vğ‘¢ğ‘£u\neq v be nodes of GğºG. Let pğ‘p and qğ‘q be the unique ports of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} linked to uğ‘¢u and vğ‘£v, respectively. Let gğ‘”g be the port assignment of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} given by g=Pâˆ–{p,q}ğ‘”ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘g=P\setminus\{p,q\}. We have gâˆˆPowâ€‹(P)Îµğ‘”Powsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ€g\in\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}} since (nâˆ’2)â€‹Â modÂ â€‹2=Îµğ‘›2Â modÂ 2ğœ€(n-2)\mbox{{\ mod }}2={\mbox{$\varepsilon$}}.

Since it is omniconjugated, graph Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} has a KekulÃ© state Wğ‘ŠW with (W|P)=gconditionalğ‘Šğ‘ƒğ‘”(W|P)=g. Every edge eğ‘’e that contains a port râˆˆgğ‘Ÿğ‘”r\in g is in Wğ‘ŠW. Since Wğ‘ŠW is a KekulÃ© state of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}, it follows that eâˆ‰Wğ‘’ğ‘Še\notin W for every edge eâˆˆGğ‘’ğºe\in G that contains some node of GğºG other than uğ‘¢u and vğ‘£v. The two edges eğ‘’e of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} incident with pğ‘p and qğ‘q are not in Wğ‘ŠW. Since Wğ‘ŠW is a KekulÃ© state of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}, it follows that uğ‘¢u is element of a unique edge eğ‘’e of Wğ‘ŠW. It follows that vğ‘£v is the other endpoint of eğ‘’e. This proves that uğ‘¢u and vğ‘£v are linked in GğºG. â–¡â–¡\Box

Section 3.3.1 of [17] presents a topological design program for omniconjugated models that have properties similar to those of our omniconjugated graphs. We transfer this idea to omniconjugated graphs in the following way.

Starting with an omniconjugated graph GğºG, the question is: what kinds of operations on GğºG are allowed that preserve its property of being omnicojugated? It turns out that operations like Op.vi and Op.vii of [17] are allowed because of Theorem 2.6. It is also easy to see that the operations Op.ii, Op.v, and Op.iv are preserved in the following sense:

Lemma 4

Let GğºG be an omniconjugated graph. Let Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} be obtained from GğºG by applying the following two types of operations:
Op.ii. Add arbitrary edges between internal nodes.
Op.v. Replace the edge to a port by two edges and a node of degree 2.
Then Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} is omniconjugated.

Lemma 5

Op.iv. Let Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} be a graph with port pâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²p^{\prime} and let Gâ€²â€²superscriptğºâ€²â€²G^{\prime\prime} be a graph with port pâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘â€²â€²p^{\prime\prime}. Let graph GğºG be obtained from Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} and Gâ€²â€²superscriptğºâ€²â€²G^{\prime\prime} by removing the two ports and identifying their incident edges. Then GğºG is omniconjugated if and only if Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} and Gâ€²â€²superscriptğºâ€²â€²G^{\prime\prime} are omniconjugated.

For example, as indicated in [17, Scheme 3.1], we can apply Op.ii twice to the basic model A6subscriptğ´6A_{6} to obtain the basic model B, which is therefore also omniconjugated.

Starting with graph Î”3subscriptÎ”3\Delta_{3}, one can apply Op.iv to obtain omniconjugated graphs with arbitrary many ports. For this purpose, we therefore do not need the graphs Î”nsubscriptÎ”ğ‘›\Delta_{n} with n>3ğ‘›3n>3.

In Theorem 2.6, we described a transformation from a graph GğºG into a graph Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} that has the same KekulÃ© cell. It follows that Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} is omniconjugated if and only if GğºG is omniconjugated. We conjecture that every omniconjugated graph in which all nodes have degree â‰¤3absent3\leq 3 can be obtained by starting with the basic models A2subscriptğ´2A_{2} and Î”3subscriptÎ”3\Delta_{3} and applying Theorem 2.6 and the Lemmas 4 and 5.

5 Functional Cells and Controlled Switches

In this section, we build upon the ideas of Chapter 6 of [17]. The idea of this chapter is that an alternating path between a pair of ports forms an open channel, and that the absence of any alternating path means closure of the channel.

A cell KâŠ†Powâ€‹(P)ğ¾Powğ‘ƒK\subseteq\mbox{{Pow}}(P) becomes a functional cell by specifying an initial element k0âˆˆKsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ¾k_{0}\in K and a linearly independent system of channels to probe and modify the current element of the cell. See the example given at the end of section 2.2.

5.1 A cell for the conjunction

Section 6.3 of [17] contains 15 of the 16 binary boolean operators implemented with pyracylene-based structures bearing six ports in various patterns. The only missing operator is the conjunction. Since Â¬Aâˆ§Bğ´ğµ\neg A\land B is available in structure 6.8 (p.Â 140) of [17], the conjunction can be realized in pyracylene by taking a nonzero initial state.

We now sketch an approach that yields a simpler graph. We first design the functional cell. Let k0=âˆ…subscriptğ‘˜0k_{0}=\emptyset be the initial element. In the style of [17], we choose two input channels Ağ´A and BğµB and a test channel Tğ‘‡T. Since we want to model the conjunction of the inputs, test channel Tğ‘‡T must be open if and only if both input channels are signalled. Therefore, the cell Kğ¾K must contain the elements âˆ…\emptyset, Ağ´A, BğµB, AâŠ•Bdirect-sumğ´ğµA\oplus B, and AâŠ•BâŠ•Tdirect-sumğ´ğµğ‘‡A\oplus B\oplus T. Since channel Tğ‘‡T must be closed in the states âˆ…\emptyset, Ağ´A, BğµB, cell Kğ¾K must not contain the elements Tğ‘‡T, AâŠ•Tdirect-sumğ´ğ‘‡A\oplus T, and BâŠ•Tdirect-sumğµğ‘‡B\oplus T.

Since all eight port assignments mentioned should be different, the smallest candidate is a cell with 4 ports and 5 elements. The solution happens to occur as cell K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1} in the classification in the proof of Lemma 2 when we take A={a,b}ğ´ğ‘ğ‘A=\{a,b\}, B={c,d}ğµğ‘ğ‘‘B=\{c,d\}, and T={b,d}ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘‘T=\{b,d\}.

A disadvantage of this solution is that both ports of test channel T={b,d}ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘‘T=\{b,d\} are used in the input channels. It may be difficult to independently signal Ağ´A and BğµB and probe Tğ‘‡T.

5.2 Reading output without disabling the switch

The example discussed above has an even more fundamental problem, which it shares with the example in section 2.2 and the results of [17]: if the test whether the output channel Tğ‘‡T is open is performed by signalling the channel, the cell moves to a state where it no longer satisfies its specification.

The point is discussed by [17] on page 149. She distinguishes signalling a channel by sending a soliton through it and reading a channel by means of a polaron. A polaron can be thought of as a double soliton [14]. In order to use the output of one cell as an input of another cell, we would like to read the output by means of solitons. This, however, requires that signalling the output channel leaves the cell in a state equivalent to the state before the output was read.

In the start state, and in all states reachable before the output is read, all inputs should be possible. In some but not all of these states, the output channel Tğ‘‡T should be open. This implies that signalling Tğ‘‡T when it is open, can bring the cell in a state where some of the input channels are not open. We therefore have to relax the requirement that input channels are always open, but since input must always be possible, we have to share inputs over more than one channel.

We therefore define an input socket to consist of a pair (A,B)ğ´ğµ(A,B) of parallel channels of the form A={p,r}ğ´ğ‘ğ‘ŸA=\{p,r\}, B={q,r}ğµğ‘ğ‘ŸB=\{q,r\} for ports pğ‘p, qğ‘q, and rğ‘Ÿr, such that always either Ağ´A is open and BğµB is closed, or vice versa. When a soliton is sent to a socket, it will travel through an open channel of the two.

Remark 5

Note that we require that the two parallel channels of the socket share a port. In fact, if the parallel channels Ağ´A and BğµB are disjoint, a soliton sent through the pair can enter via a port of Ağ´A and exit via a port of BğµB, so that an unintended channel is signalled. In order to reckon with this possibility, one would have to impose additional requirements. â–¡â–¡\Box

Example 4

The simplest case, called the Y-cell, has one input socket and one output channel. Let the socket consist of the channels Ağ´A and BğµB, and let Tğ‘‡T be the output channel. The vectors Ağ´A, BğµB, Tğ‘‡T are supposed to be linearly independent. We postulate that K=k0âŠ•Lğ¾direct-sumsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ¿K=k_{0}\oplus L where L={âˆ…,A,AâŠ•T,AâŠ•BâŠ•T}ğ¿ğ´direct-sumğ´ğ‘‡direct-sumğ´ğµğ‘‡L=\{\emptyset,A,A\oplus T,A\oplus B\oplus T\}.

The state space Kğ¾K is a translation of Lğ¿L. Either space consists of 4 states with three possible transitions. In the diagram, a transition indicated with channel cğ‘c corresponds to the operation xâ†¦xâŠ•cmaps-toğ‘¥direct-sumğ‘¥ğ‘x\mapsto x\oplus c.

In all states, either channel Ağ´A or channel BğµB is available, and toggling this channel opens or closes the output channel Tğ‘‡T.

The simplest graph with such a KekulÃ© cell is a tree with 5 ports and 3 internal nodes. In this case, the vector space Powâ€‹(P)ÎµPowsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ€\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}} over ğ”¹ğ”¹\mathbb{B}Â has dimension 4 (16 elements). The KekulÃ© cell has 8 elements. We use the initial state and the input socket (A,B)ğ´ğµ(A,B) and the output channel Tğ‘‡T as depicted in the leftmost graph.

In the initial state depicted on the left, only channel Ağ´A is open. If channel Ağ´A is signalled, we get in state middle-left where the channels Ağ´A and Tğ‘‡T are open. If Tğ‘‡T is signalled there, we get in state middle-right where the channels BğµB and Tğ‘‡T are open. If BğµB is signalled there, we get in the rightmost state where channel BğµB is the only open channel.

This state of affairs can also be realized in a pyracylene derivative as shown below. The ports A1subscriptğ´1A_{1} and T1subscriptğ‘‡1T_{1} start with a double bond in the initial state k0subscriptğ‘˜0k_{0}.

In this case, Powâ€‹(P)ÎµPowsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ€\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}} has dimension 4. The KekulÃ© cell has 12 elements. From the start state k0subscriptğ‘˜0k_{0} only four of them are reachable by sending solitons over the channels Ağ´A, BğµB, Tğ‘‡T, but, e.g., one reaches the origin âˆ…\emptyset by sending a soliton from A1subscriptğ´1A_{1} to T1subscriptğ‘‡1T_{1}. The origin has four different KekulÃ© states, whereas k0subscriptğ‘˜0k_{0} and k0âŠ•AâŠ•BâŠ•Tdirect-sumsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ´ğµğ‘‡k_{0}\oplus A\oplus B\oplus T have only two different KekulÃ© states. This suggests that the origin is physically much more stable than the physical states corresponding to k0subscriptğ‘˜0k_{0} and k0âŠ•AâŠ•BâŠ•Tdirect-sumsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ´ğµğ‘‡k_{0}\oplus A\oplus B\oplus T. The port assignments k0âŠ•Adirect-sumsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ´k_{0}\oplus A and k0âŠ•AâŠ•Tdirect-sumsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ´ğ‘‡k_{0}\oplus A\oplus T have only one KekulÃ© state. Remark 6

Is there a graph GğºG with four ports pğ‘p, qğ‘q, rğ‘Ÿr, tğ‘¡t, such that the above structure can be realized by taking A={p,r}ğ´ğ‘ğ‘ŸA=\{p,r\}, B={q,r}ğµğ‘ğ‘ŸB=\{q,r\}, T={t,r}ğ‘‡ğ‘¡ğ‘ŸT=\{t,r\}? 5.3 Splitting for feedback

One may decide that, when an output channel Tğ‘‡T is read and toggled, a signal is sent back through Tğ‘‡T to reset the cell to its unread state. Since the output should also be sent forward to be used, we need a splitter: a cell with one input channel or socket and two output channels that are both opened when an input signal arrives.

We use an input socket (A,B)ğ´ğµ(A,B) and output channels Sğ‘†S and Tğ‘‡T. Let the origin âˆ…\emptyset be the initial state. Then the cell must contain 0, Ağ´A, AâŠ•Sdirect-sumğ´ğ‘†A\oplus S, AâŠ•SâŠ•Tdirect-sumğ´ğ‘†ğ‘‡A\oplus S\oplus T, AâŠ•SâŠ•TâŠ•Bdirect-sumğ´ğ‘†ğ‘‡ğµA\oplus S\oplus T\oplus B. Since the channels Sğ‘†S and Tğ‘‡T must be closed in states âˆ…\emptyset and AâŠ•SâŠ•TâŠ•Bdirect-sumğ´ğ‘†ğ‘‡ğµA\oplus S\oplus T\oplus B, the cell must not contain Sğ‘†S, Tğ‘‡T, AâŠ•SâŠ•Bdirect-sumğ´ğ‘†ğµA\oplus S\oplus B, and AâŠ•TâŠ•Bdirect-sumğ´ğ‘‡ğµA\oplus T\oplus B. Since (A,B)ğ´ğµ(A,B) is a socket, the cell must not contain BğµB, AâŠ•Bdirect-sumğ´ğµA\oplus B, SâŠ•Tdirect-sumğ‘†ğ‘‡S\oplus T, and SâŠ•TâŠ•Bdirect-sumğ‘†ğ‘‡ğµS\oplus T\oplus B. The cell may or may not contain the elements AâŠ•Tdirect-sumğ´ğ‘‡A\oplus T, BâŠ•Sdirect-sumğµğ‘†B\oplus S, and BâŠ•Tdirect-sumğµğ‘‡B\oplus T.

The indene molecule has a graph with a KekulÃ© cell with these properties, as depicted here. The 9 interior nodes form a pentagon and a hexagon. In this case Powâ€‹(P)ÎµPowsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ€\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}} has dimension 5, and 32 elements. The KekulÃ© cell has 18 elements. We use the input socket (A,B)ğ´ğµ(A,B) and the output channels Sğ‘†S, Tğ‘‡T as depicted. Incidentally, Sğ‘†S and Tğ‘‡T also form a socket. Initially, there are double bonds at both ports of channel Ağ´A and at the eastern port of Sğ‘†S. Indene has several solutions of this type, but all of these have initially three double bonds at ports, have output channels combined in a socket, and have the elements AâŠ•Tdirect-sumğ´ğ‘‡A\oplus T, BâŠ•Sdirect-sumğµğ‘†B\oplus S, and BâŠ•Tdirect-sumğµğ‘‡B\oplus T in the KekulÃ© cell.

6 Conclusions

In this paper, we presented a theoretical investigation into the computational possibilities of polycyclic hydrocarbons, based on connectivity via molecular paths with alternating single and double bonds. We confirmed and extended the results presented in [17]. Moreover, we introduced the new concepts of cell and functional cell in order to characterize the switching behaviour of single unsaturated polycyclic hydrocarbon molecules. We regard this as an interesting and fascinating subject, both from the point of view of new chemistry and new applications of mathematics, as well as for the speculations about their potential for molecular computation. We showed that it is, in principle, possible to build logical switches with Ï€ğœ‹\pi-conjugated systems of unsaturated polycyclic hydrocarbons, but we are fully aware of the tremendous technical problems in realizing this potential. Anyway, the notion of functional cell emerging from our work is, in its own right, an interesting starting point for an alternative abstract model for computation. We showed that it encompasses logical switches; it would be interesting to investigate whether and how, e.g., data storage can be modeled with it.

So far, we have not yet found a connection between our investigations and quantum computing, although such a connection might very wel exist. The relevant properties of unsaturated polycyclic hydrocarbons are a direct consequence of the quantum mechanical behaviour of electrons, but there seems no role for entanglement here, which renders the connection with quantum computing still elusive.
